items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid contact with any standing flood water which may remain.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are rising and forecast to continue rising at the Torksey river gauge as a result of snowmelt and rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 23:00 tonight, 13/03/2023. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point, and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. However, further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high beyond 16/03/2023. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our field team staff have closed the pointing doors at Torksey today. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:30 tomorrow, 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Warwick river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Rugby and Bidford including Warwick, Stratford upon Avon, caravan parks and farmland. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into Monday night 13/03/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Tuesday 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Matlock and Church Wilne river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from midnight tonight, 13/03/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Darley Dale, Cromford, Matlock, Whatstandwell, Belper, Duffield, Milford, Little Eaton, and the B5057 between Darley Bridge and Two Dales Road. Also affected are some low lying farmland in the Church Wilne and Draycott areas and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley.
We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow evening on 14/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Ashford river gauge as a result of rainfall and snowmelt.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected from 17:00 today, 13/03/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas.   
  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 14/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Mythe Bridge River gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin early hours tomorrow, 14/03/23.   
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore.
Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.8m to 4.3m, Haw Bridge 4.6m to 5.1m, Sandhurst 3.1m to 3.6m, Friday, 17/03/23.    
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week, and river levels may continue to rise. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling at the Dernford river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. Flooding is affecting River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.
Further rain is forecast for the next 24 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding continues. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are reaching peak in the Upper River Aire, Eller Beck and Waller Hill Beck due to rainfall this afternoon, Monday 13/03/2023. River levels will be at their highest between 19:00 this evening and 09:00 tomorrow, Tuesday 14/03/2023. This Flood Alert is being issued as washlands in the Upper Aire are forecast to fill. Flooding is forecast to affect low lying land in locations near the River Aire, Eller Beck and Waller Hill Beck.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise on the River Ure due to snowmelt. Low lying land is expected to be most affected, including agricultural land and local roads in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Bishop Monkton. Levels are currently forecast to peak overnight on Monday at Masham and into Tuesday, 14/03/2023. Further rainfall is forecast overnight Monday and into Tuesday, 14/03/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen on the River Lune; River Conder due to steady rainfall overnight and during Monday morning.
Flooding is possible at River Lune, Conder and Keer and other watercourses from Kirkby Lonsdale to Galgate including Gressingham, Carnforth, Hornby, Wray, Bentham and Lancaster from 2pm on 13/03/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon and into this evening.
River levels are expected to remain high at the Caton; Galgate gauge for the rest of the day.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 09:30 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin tomorrow morning, Tuesday 14/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.1 to 3.6m on Wednesday morning, 15/03/23.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for a few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Tuesday 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high and forecast to rise further on the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwent Water lake level due to heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Flooding is expected at low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site between 6:00 PM on the Monday the 13th of March through into Tuesday morning. The forecast is for rain throughout the evening. This may have an effect on the river and lake levels and we will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River levels are rising on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Rivers Kent and Bela due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Rivers Kent and Bela, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the River Cherwell as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is expected, especially in the Thrupp area. 
The forecast this evening is for outbreaks of rain which may turn heavy at times. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to snowmelt. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade. Levels will continue to rise steadily overnight into Tuesday, 14/03/2023. The current forecast is 3m overnight into Tuesday, 14/03/2023 at York (Viking).
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Bewdley river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin overnight tonight, 13/03/23.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn. B4195 Stourport Road Dog Lane Bewdley and Riverside Path Stourport. 
Predicted peaks:- Bewdley 4.2m to 4.7m on Thursday, 16/03, Worcester 4.5m to 5m on Thursday, 16/03, Diglis 4.1m to 4.6m on Thursday, 16/03, Kempsey Yacht Club 6.2m to 6.7m on Friday, 17/03, Saxons Lode 4.5m to 5.0m on Friday, 17/03.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week, and river levels may continue to rise. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Wey as a result of rainfall. Therefore, flooding of footpaths and farmland is possible over today 13/03/23, especially in the Godalming and Bordon areas. Levels started to rise yesterday evening after a period of heavy rainfall and have responded to rainfall over today particularly on the Hell Ditch. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over this evening. We expect river levels to continue to fall overnight.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise on the Lower River Eden due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe.
No property flooding is expected.
Further rainfall is forecast and river levels will continue to rise throughout this evening, Monday the 13th of March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Nidd due to snowmelt. Areas most at risk include land around the upper River Nidd and its tributaries including How Stean Beck, Blayshaw Gill, Ramsgill Beck, Lul Beck, Foster Beck, Fosse Gill, Fell Beck and Darley Beck. Levels are currently forecast to peak at 10:30 PM at Pateley Bridge this evening, 13/03/2023. Further rainfall is forecast overnight on Monday and into Tuesday, 14/03/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10 AM on Tuesday,14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise slowly at the Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Cae Howel gauges following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 4.4 to 4.9m Tuesday morning, 14/03/23. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, Tuesday 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Evenlode and Glyme as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and farmland is possible overnight, 13/03/22, especially in the Evenlode area. 
The forecast this evening is for outbreaks of rain which may turn heavy at times. We expect river levels to begin rising this evening in response to rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are forecast to remain high at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Monday, 13/03/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Tuesday 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels will start to fall this afternoon as rainfall ceases.
No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no further rainfall for the rest of the day.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge & Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 6.1 to 6.5m tomorrow afternoon 14/03/23, Montford 6 to 6.4m, Welshbridge 4 to 4.4m both on Wednesday morning 15/03/23, Buildwas 5.3 to 5.7m on Wednesday evening, 15/03/23, Bridgnorth 4.2 to 4.7m Thursday morning 16/03/23. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. The Frankwell barriers have been deployed. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise on the Lower River Calder this this evening, Monday 13/03/2023. River levels will be at their highest at around 23:00 on Monday 13/03/2023. Overtopping of the river bank could affect locations around Calder View Road in Mirfield, with low lying land expected to be most affected. We do not currently expect flooding to properties.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
This message will be updated by 09:00 am on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, Tuesday 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.

We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into Monday night 13/03/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message:
River levels have risen on the River Ure due to snowmelt. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ure, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Roecliffe Caravan Park. Flooding is affecting Roecliffe Caravan Park from late afternoon on Monday, 13/03/2023. Further rainfall is forecast overnight. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to snowmelt. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Hay-On-Wye, Bredwardine and Old Wye Bridge river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land & roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine & Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 2.4m to 2.8m this evening, Monday 13/03/23, Bredwardine 4.30m to 4.70m on Tuesday morning, 14/03/23, Belmont 4.30m to 4.80m on Tuesday morning, 14/03/23, Old Wye Bridge 3.80m to 4.30m on Tuesday morning, 14/03/23, Mordiford 4.20m to 4.60m on Tuesday evening, 14/03/23, Ross on Wye 3.10m to 3.60m on Wednesday morning, 15/03/23. Further rainfall is forecasted. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River Nene levels continue to remain high since the heavy rainfall and snow last week, which led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Although river levels have receded, there is some further rainfall forecast for this evening, Monday 13th March, and overnight. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings remains possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 14/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Sutton Gault, Earith and Welney river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Monday 13 March and is likely to continue for the first half of the week. Flooding is affecting Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes, including the causeways at Earith, Sutton Gault and Welney.

This information is correct as of 15:00 on Monday 13 March. The Welney causeway currently has 24 cm of water on the road. Earith has approximately 5 cm of water on the road and the causeway at Sutton Gault has 37 cm of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated again before 08:00 tomorrow morning, 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Shardlow and Willington river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until at least Thursday, 16/03/23.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow, 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Halesowen Manor Way river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.     
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels have risen at the Tern - Walcot and Rodington river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, tuesday 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to snowmelt. Areas most at risk include properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge.
Flooding is affecting properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendall Bridge to Millennium Bridge from midnight on Tuesday morning, 14/03/2023. The current forecast level of the River Ouse is 3m overnight into Tuesday, 14/03/2023 at York (Viking). We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 8:30 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message:
River levels are rising on the Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are expected to remain high for the rest of today, Monday 13th March.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to begin overnight tonight, 13/03/23.  
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme may become operational from 03:00, 14/03/23.  
Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 6.2m to 6.7m on Friday, 17/03. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next week, and river levels may continue to rise. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message: River levels have risen at the Leintwardine and Onibury river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. Predicted peaks:- Leintwardine 1.3m to 1.8m, tomorrow morning, 14/03/23. Onibury peaked at 1.74m this afternoon, 13/03/23. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, Tuesday 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Tamar has now reduced. Rainfall overnight was less than forecast and river levels have remained below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels remain high at the Clay Coton river gauge as a result of  heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into Monday night 13/03/23. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast and clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Tuesday 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Further rainfall is forecast over the next day. 
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Rainfall overnight has caused the River Dee to rise and it will continue to do so due to further rainfall throughout today and tomorrow. Access to Townfield Lane is likely to be cut off from around the early hours(02:00) on 14/03/23. The Dee is forecast to peak at 8.6m at around 21:00 on 14/03/23.  
  
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is forecast to begin between 7 and 9pm this evening, 13/03/23. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Maesbrook. Predicted peak:- Llanymynech 4.4 to 4.9m tomorrow morning, 14/03/23. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 10am on 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise on the River Nidd due to snowmelt. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Nidd, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly land around the lower River Nidd and its tributaries including Sand Beck, Sike Beck, Pool Beck and Great Gutter from 10:30 PM on Monday, 13/03/2023.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels are high but steady on Sunday the 12th March 2022 at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. We expect the River Avon to remain high for the next coming days; its possible there will be some flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   

The weather forecast for late Sunday and into Monday suggests some large rainfall totals. We will continue to closely monitor the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  This message will be updated on the 13 March 2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to snowmelt. Areas most at risk include Naburn Lock buildings and Lock cottages. The current forecast level of the River Ouse is 3m overnight into Tuesday, 14/03/2023 at York (Viking).
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this flood warning if necessary. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 8:30 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to begin between 7 and 9pm this evening, 13/03/23. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Melverley including Melverley to Melverley Green and Ponthen to Melverley roads. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 4.4 to 4.9m tomorrow morning, 14/03/23, and Crew Green 6.1 to 6.5m tomorrow afternoon, 14/03/23. Further rainfall is forecast over the next week. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 10am on 14/03/23, or as the situation changes.

This alert remains in force due to raised levels on the River Ure following snowmelt and overnight rainfall on Sunday 12th March 2023. The areas most at risk are low lying roads, paths and farmland near watercourses. Flooding of areas near Low Houses and Bainbridge is possible throughout Monday 13th March 2023. Please exercise caution around low lying areas and put any relevant flood plans into action. We will continue to monitor the forecast and river levels and will update this message by 16:00 on Monday afternoon or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise on the River Ure due to snowmelt.  Areas most at risk include low lying land and local roads around Lower Dunsforth, including Ings Road, Mary Lane and the Ings from late afternoon on Monday, 13/03/2023. Further rainfall is forecast this evening.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Seven due to snowmelt. Areas most at risk include land around the River Seven and it's tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, including properties in Sinnington and to the east of Normanby. Levels are currently forecast to peak overnight on Monday and into Tuesday, 14/03/2023. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River Nene river levels remain high since the heavy rain and snow last week. Further rainfall is expected this evening and overnight, with more in the following days. During periods of high tide, the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are operating the Whittlesey washlands to help manage the situation, but the B1040 is not expected to be flooded. This Flood Warning is expected to remain in place until at least Tuesday 14th March 2023, whilst river and tide levels remain high. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 09:00 on 14/03/23, or before, if the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for further unsettled weather throughout the week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for further unsettled weather throughout the week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River Nene levels continue to remain high since the heavy rainfall and snow last week, which led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. Although river levels have receded, there is some further rainfall forecast for this evening, Monday 13th March, and overnight. Flooding to gardens, driveways or outbuildings remains possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued at this time. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 09:00 on 14/03/23, or before if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: County Durham, Darlington, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire, Stockton-on-Tees

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the Lower Tees this evening and overnight, 13/03/2023 as a result of heavy rainfall and snowmelt. Areas most at risk are riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. Rainfall is forecast overnight, 13/03/2023. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Our incident response staff will be closing phase 1 Yarm flood gates this evening, 13/03/2023 and they will remain closed for the rest of the week due to unsettled weather conditions. 

This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 14/03/2023.

items.description: Middle River Mersey catchment including areas near Bramhall, Stockport, Sale, Altrincham and Urmston

items.message:
We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around Micker, Cringle, Sinderland and Poynton Brooks and their tributaries.  Rainfall overnight has caused the River Mersey to rise and it will continue to do so due to further rainfall throughout today and tomorrow. Access to Ford Lane is likely to be affected from (20:00) on 13/03/23. The Mersey is forecast to peak around 21:00 on 13/03/23, however levels will remain high into the evening and the early hours of 14/03/23.  
  
Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated  tomorrow, 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Rye has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise this evening, Monday 13/03/2023, due to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Rye, including low lying land and roads around Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck, Spittle Beck and including properties at Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9 AM on 14/03/2023, or as the situation changes.
